citation.abstract:
Investigate brain radiation dose in complex cases arising from two stereotactic linac designs. Present a method for comparing brain dose to published data.
Two head designs were considered: Beam Modulator (BM) and Agility (AG). 12 patients treated on BM were re-planned with AG. Planning objectives were: minimize brain dose, and satisfy target coverage and organs-at-risk dose constraints. Each of 36 targets was analysed for conformity (CI-Paddick), gradient (GI), and homogeneity index (HI). Total volume (V) and brain-minus-PTV (BMP) receiving 80% (V80/BMP80) down to 25% (V25/BMP25) of prescription dose and mean doses were evaluated. System differences were statistically evaluated using Wilcoxon signed-rank test. Power-law models and prediction bands for V/BMP were generated based on BM data.
The median CI-Paddick was 0.74 and 0.76 for BM and AG, respectively (p=0.04). The median GI was 5.5 and 6.1 (p<0.01) and for HI was 1.17 and 1.16 for BM and AG respectively (p<0.01). V80/BMP80 down to V40/BMP40 were not statistically different between the systems whereas BMP25 was weakly different (p=0.02). AG exhibited a lower mean BMP dose (4.1Gy) than BM (4.6Gy) (p<0.01). Power-law models for V/BMP showed excellent (R(2)>0.80) agreement for the dose levels studied, and comparable results with published data.
Treatment plans of equivalent quality were attained with AG compared to BM. Advances in Knowledge: The AG system involves a novel collimation design. The present paper demonstrates equivalent or improved brain dose for complex, multi-target cases using AG versus an older stereotactic system.
